field_edited_text.value:
Maryland Port Administration

b

he 1
k2

L 320 B



Modern container loading operations



Break-bulk cargo







There are four types of cargo handled
by the port. The first two described below
- containerized freight and breakbulk
cargo - are termed general cargo.

Containerized Freight - Baltimore
ranks second among East Coast and Gulf
Coast ports in moving containers, the 20 to
40 foot, van-like boxes that can be lifted
off a ship and placed directly on a truck
chassis. Shipping cargo in containers
reduces handling time and damage. Balti-
more was a pioneer in container handling,
receiving its first container cargo in 1963
when other ports were skeptically waiting
to see if the new cargo-handling technol-
ogy had any future. Baltimore’s early lead
has paid off. Between 1970 and 1976 the
volume of containerized cargo shipped
through the harbor tripled. By January 1977
the Port of Baltimore had moved its first
million containers and by April 1981 it had
handled-its second million.





Breakbulk Cargo - With approximately
88 berths, six-million square feet of
enclosed storage, and five-million cubic
feet of cold storage, the port is capable of
handling large quantities of mixed cargo,
known as breakbulk, which requires
individualized loading and unloading.
Breakbulk cargo is typified by smaller
articles bound for several locations and
specialized items like yachts, air condition-
ing equipment, and farm machinery. In
recent yedrs the port has also become a
leading depot for “project cargo,” in which
all the components for a single project
(for example, a factory or even an entire
village) are marshalled together from many
suppliers, packed, loaded, and ultimately
shipped to their destination. The port has
been able to capture a large share of the
project cargo bound for the Mideast and
Southeast Asia because of its proximity to
many Midwest and East Coast firms special-
izing in multiphased projects, its expansive
rail and highway access network, its exten-
sive storage facilities, and the variety and
flexibility of its cargo handling equipment.





17

Maryland Port Administration
